path_1.title: On Her Majesty's Secret Service (1969)
path_1.feeling: Classic Bond thrills with a memorable emotional sting.

path_1.title: Madagascar (2005)
path_1.feeling: Energetic and cute, but mostly a lightweight diversion.

path_1.title: Sleeping Beauty (1959)
path_1.feeling: Gorgeous and timeless, if a bit distant emotionally.

path_1.title: George of the Jungle (1997)
path_1.feeling: Goofy fun in spots, but too slapstick for me.

path_1.title: Corky Romano (2001)
path_1.feeling: Broad, clumsy gags left me mostly cringing.

path_1.title: Catch Me If You Can (2002)
path_1.feeling: Slick, charming and propulsive in all the right ways.

path_1.title: Food, Inc. (2008)
path_1.feeling: Eye-opening and infuriating in a way that sticks with me.

path_1.title: 8 Mile (2002)
path_1.feeling: Gritty and sincere with a compelling underdog pulse.

path_1.title: Dracula (Bram Stoker's Dracula) (1992)
path_1.feeling: Lush, operatic horror that casts a moody spell.

path_1.title: Maltese Falcon, The (1941)
path_1.feeling: Tight, tough and endlessly watchable noir.

path_1.title: Child's Play (1988)
path_1.feeling: Fun concept, but the camp undercuts the creep.

path_1.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_1.feeling: Sweeping, earnest and surprisingly stirring.

path_1.title: Vanilla Sky (2001)
path_1.feeling: Intriguing ideas, uneven execution.

path_1.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_1.feeling: High-concept romance with slick, engaging momentum.

path_1.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_1.feeling: Ambitious and moving, even when it gets a bit heavy-handed.

path_1.title: Panic Room (2002)
path_1.feeling: Tense, well-crafted confinement thriller.

path_1.title: True Grit (2010)
path_1.feeling: Solid craftsmanship that never fully grabbed me.

path_1.title: 'burbs, The (1989)
path_1.feeling: Quirky paranoia comedy that only lands sporadically.

path_1.title: Concert, Le (2009)
path_1.feeling: Warm, crowd-pleasing and musically uplifting.

path_1.title: Glitter (2001)
path_1.feeling: Glossy melodrama with little spark.

path_1.title: National Lampoon's Van Wilder (2002)
path_1.feeling: Juvenile laughs wore thin fast.

path_1.title: Being John Malkovich (1999)
path_1.feeling: Inventive, funny and strangely affecting.

path_1.title: Fried Green Tomatoes (1991)
path_1.feeling: Heartfelt storytelling with a comforting warmth.

path_1.title: Dr. Dolittle (1998)
path_1.feeling: Mildly amusing, mostly forgettable.

path_1.title: Munich (2005)
path_1.feeling: Gripping and morally thorny throughout.

path_1.title: Mystic River (2003)
path_1.feeling: Somber, powerful and superbly acted.

path_1.title: Wing Commander (1999)
path_1.feeling: Earnest but generic and clunky.

path_1.title: Superman II (1980)
path_1.feeling: Classic superhero charm with memorable villains.

path_1.title: X2: X-Men United (2003)
path_1.feeling: Smart, propulsive and satisfying ensemble action.

path_1.title: Charlie Brown Christmas, A (1965)
path_1.feeling: Simple, sincere and perfectly bittersweet.

path_2.title: On Her Majesty's Secret Service (1969)
path_2.feeling: Sleek, wintry Bond with real stakes and a tender undercurrent that kept me engaged.

path_2.title: Madagascar (2005)
path_2.feeling: Zippy and loud with a few laughs, but the zany energy wears thin for me.

path_2.title: Sleeping Beauty (1959)
path_2.feeling: Elegant, painterly classic I respect more for its craft than it moves me.

path_2.title: George of the Jungle (1997)
path_2.feeling: Goofy and harmless, sporadically fun but mostly too broad for my taste.

path_2.title: Corky Romano (2001)
path_2.feeling: Grating, one-note slapstick that never finds a groove.

path_2.title: Catch Me If You Can (2002)
path_2.feeling: Breezy, slick cat-and-mouse with charm and craft to spare.

path_2.title: Food, Inc. (2008)
path_2.feeling: Clear, infuriating, well-sourced expose that sharpened my perspective.

path_2.title: 8 Mile (2002)
path_2.feeling: Gritty, focused underdog story with real pulse even if it hits familiar beats.

path_2.title: Dracula (Bram Stoker's Dracula) (1992)
path_2.feeling: Lush, gothic romance-horror that seduces on style even when it overreaches.

path_2.title: Maltese Falcon, The (1941)
path_2.feeling: Lean, shadowy noir with crackling dialogue and moral bite.

path_2.title: Child's Play (1988)
path_2.feeling: Clever premise and some jolts, more fun than frightening for me.

path_2.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_2.feeling: Polished, big-hearted classic I admire more than I adore.

path_2.title: Vanilla Sky (2001)
path_2.feeling: Ambitious, dreamy head-trip that intrigues more than it coheres.

path_2.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_2.feeling: Romantic, fate-vs-free-will sci-fi that's thoughtful if a bit tidy.

path_2.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_2.feeling: Grand, emotional space odyssey with ideas and awe that outweigh the schmaltz.

path_2.title: Panic Room (2002)
path_2.feeling: Tight, muscular home-invasion thriller with cool precision if limited scope.

path_2.title: True Grit (2010)
path_2.feeling: Sturdy and well-acted, but its measured gait keeps me at arm's length.

path_2.title: 'burbs, The (1989)
path_2.feeling: Suburban paranoia played broad

path_2.title: Concert, Le (2009)
path_2.feeling: Sweet, crowd-pleasing redemption arc with heart, if a little tidy and contrived.

path_2.title: Glitter (2001)
path_2.feeling: Thin, glossy melodrama that never finds a convincing rhythm.

path_2.title: National Lampoon's Van Wilder (2002)
path_2.feeling: Bro-y hijinks with a few chuckles, mostly tired and juvenile.

path_2.title: Being John Malkovich (1999)
path_2.feeling: Wildly inventive, smart and unsettling in all the right ways.

path_2.title: Fried Green Tomatoes (1991)
path_2.feeling: Warm, gently affecting storytelling that I appreciate more than I love.

path_2.title: Dr. Dolittle (1998)
path_2.feeling: Cute animal chaos that's fine background noise, little lasting impact.

path_2.title: Munich (2005)
path_2.feeling: Sober, gripping moral labyrinth with real tension and weight.

path_2.title: Mystic River (2003)
path_2.feeling: Heavy, well-crafted tragedy with performances that linger.

path_2.title: Wing Commander (1999)
path_2.feeling: Generic space-opera beats without the grit or ideas I crave.

path_2.title: Superman II (1980)
path_2.feeling: Classic campy heroics

path_2.title: X2: X-Men United (2003)
path_2.feeling: Lean, engaging superhero stakes with enough bite to satisfy.

path_2.title: Charlie Brown Christmas, A (1965)
path_2.feeling: Simple, sincere and gently melancholic in a way that sticks.

path_2.title: On Her Majesty's Secret Service (1969)
path_2.feeling: Sleek Alpine cat-and-mouse with rare Bond vulnerability, even if some camp peeks through.

path_2.title: Madagascar (2005)
path_2.feeling: Bouncy and loud—some gags land, but it’s not my flavor.

path_2.title: Sleeping Beauty (1959)
path_2.feeling: Lush, storybook elegance I admire more for craft than I feel.

path_2.title: George of the Jungle (1997)
path_2.feeling: Goofy charm in spots, but the slapstick wears thin fast.

path_2.title: Corky Romano (2001)
path_2.feeling: Grating, witless farce that tries way too hard.

path_2.title: Catch Me If You Can (2002)
path_2.feeling: Breezy, sharp cat-and-mouse with craft and momentum I relish.

path_2.title: Food, Inc. (2008)
path_2.feeling: Clear, infuriating systemic exposé that sticks in the craw.

path_2.title: 8 Mile (2002)
path_2.feeling: Grimy, propulsive underdog tale that works beyond the raps.

path_2.title: Dracula (Bram Stoker's Dracula) (1992)
path_2.feeling: Sumptuous Gothic excess—uneven, but the mood and imagery hook me.

path_2.title: Maltese Falcon, The (1941)
path_2.feeling: Tight, hard-boiled noir where attitude and intrigue still sing.

path_2.title: Child's Play (1988)
path_2.feeling: Fun premise and jolts, but it plays more camp than dread for me.

path_2.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_2.feeling: Lush and earnest—charming, if a bit too saccharine for me.

path_2.title: Vanilla Sky (2001)
path_2.feeling: Intriguing dream logic, but the melodrama keeps me at arm’s length.

path_2.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_2.feeling: Romantic, high-concept glide—engaging even with sanded edges.

path_2.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_2.feeling: Ambitious and awe-struck, though the sentiment mutes the chillier ideas I crave.

path_2.title: Panic Room (2002)
path_2.feeling: Taut, well-engineered home-invasion puzzle that hums.

path_2.title: True Grit (2010)
path_2.feeling: Handsome, sturdy western I respect more than I feel.

path_2.title: 'burbs, The (1989)
path_2.feeling: Amusing suburban paranoia with some bite, but the tone wobbles.

path_2.title: Concert, Le (2009)
path_2.feeling: Crowd-pleasing and sentimental, but the performance payoff lands.

path_2.title: Glitter (2001)
path_2.feeling: Thin, cliché-ridden star vehicle that never finds a pulse.

path_2.title: National Lampoon's Van Wilder (2002)
path_2.feeling: Smirking, juvenile antics with few laughs for me.

path_2.title: Being John Malkovich (1999)
path_2.feeling: Wildly inventive, off-kilter identity trip that scratches my weird itch.

path_2.title: Fried Green Tomatoes (1991)
path_2.feeling: Warm, well-acted melodrama that goes down easy, if a bit tidy.

path_2.title: Dr. Dolittle (1998)
path_2.feeling: Broad, busy family fluff that rarely rises above its gimmick.

path_2.title: Munich (2005)
path_2.feeling: Grim, morally knotted manhunt staged with nerve and weight.

path_2.title: Mystic River (2003)
path_2.feeling: Brooding, heavy tragedy with strong craft and performances that linger.

path_2.title: Wing Commander (1999)
path_2.feeling: Thin, clunky space opera that never finds momentum or ideas.

path_2.title: Superman II (1980)
path_2.feeling: Charming, campy stakes with Zod fun, but the weight isn’t there for me.

path_2.title: X2: X-Men United (2003)
path_2.feeling: Sleek, character-driven mutant thriller that clicks on craft and momentum.

path_2.title: Charlie Brown Christmas, A (1965)
path_2.feeling: Simple, sincere anti-commercial melancholy that still warms me.

path_2.title: On Her Majesty's Secret Service (1969)
path_2.feeling: Bond with real stakes and alpine intrigue—still a bit campy but the melancholy lands.

path_2.title: Madagascar (2005)
path_2.feeling: Energetic and cute, but too slick and shallow for me to care.

path_2.title: Sleeping Beauty (1959)
path_2.feeling: Gorgeous classic craft I admire more than I feel, fairy‑tale thin.

path_2.title: George of the Jungle (1997)
path_2.feeling: Goofy charm in spots, but mostly broad, low‑stakes silliness.

path_2.title: Corky Romano (2001)
path_2.feeling: Grating broad comedy that misses my wavelength entirely.

path_2.title: Catch Me If You Can (2002)
path_2.feeling: Spry cat‑and‑mouse with heart and craft I can happily sink into.

path_2.feeling: Clear, enraging industry autopsy that scratches my doc‑thriller itch.

path_2.title: 8 Mile (2002)
path_2.feeling: Gritty, focused underdog drama with lived‑in stakes that work.

path_2.title: Dracula (Bram Stoker's Dracula) (1992)
path_2.feeling: Lush, operatic gothic romance—messy, but mood and imagery hook me.

path_2.feeling: Hard‑boiled, clockwork noir whose attitude and twists still sing.

path_2.feeling: Effective high‑concept slasher more fun than frightening for me.

path_2.title: Sound of Music, The (1965)
path_2.feeling: Sweeping, earnest musical I respect for craft even if it’s not my lane.

path_2.title: Vanilla Sky (2001)
path_2.feeling: Glossy, dreamy head‑trip whose emotion intrigues more than it convinces.

path_2.title: Adjustment Bureau, The (2011)
path_2.feeling: Light, idea‑driven sci‑fi romance with enough spark to keep me in.

path_2.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_2.feeling: Ambitious, awe‑struck space epic whose sentiment blunts its edge for me.

path_2.title: Panic Room (2002)
path_2.feeling: Tight, precise home‑invasion chess match—clean craft over depth.

path_2.title: True Grit (2010)
path_2.feeling: Lean, well‑made western I admire more than I connect with.

path_2.feeling: Suburban paranoia romp with playful menace that’s fun if slight.

path_2.feeling: Warm, rousing crowd‑pleaser with enough emotional payoff to work on me.

path_2.feeling: Broad, fratty antics that aren’t my flavor of comedy at all.
